executiveSummary:
• Context: Results are actuals through the last completed month (December 2025). Figures beyond that point are forecast.
  • Topline: ARR £9.4m; 12‑month ARR growth 70% (well above 19% benchmark). Gross margin stable at 78%.
  • Efficiency: Rule of 40 at 63%. CAC ratio 0.56 and LTV:CAC 6.5 indicate efficient acquisition; ARR per head 147 vs 77 benchmark.
  • Retention: Net retention 90% and gross retention 79% remain the primary drag; logo retention 85% vs 91% benchmark. NRR has trended down to ~90% in recent months.
  • Mix: Energy & Utilities (3.95m) and Life Science (2.50m) lead vertical ARR; South America (2.18m) and Asia (2.09m) are the largest regions.
  • Last 3 months: Net +£506k ARR (New +£720k, Expand +£236k, Lost -£405k, Downsell -£45k). Strength in Energy & Utilities; weakness in Finance & Professional Services and parts of Africa/North America.
  • P&L: FY25 revenue £8.38m; EBITDA -£595k (-7%) with improving trajectory; forecast turns positive from mid‑2026 as scale and spend mix improve.
  • Budget: ARR +11% vs plan; EBITDA slightly ahead of plan. Overheads ran hot (S&M +12%, G&A +38% vs budget), offset by revenue outperformance.
  • Actions: 1) Retention program to lift NRR back >100% within 2 quarters. 2) Tighten S&M and G&A while preserving CAC efficiency. 3) Double down on winning verticals/regions (E&U, Life Science; South America, Asia). 4) Address Finance & Professional Services churn drivers; reinforce African account coverage.
page1:
• Scale: ARR £9.4m across 96 customers; average ARR per customer £98k; headcount 64.
  • Growth and quality: ARR growth 70% (vs 19% benchmark). Recurring margin 83% and gross margin 78% (both above benchmarks); non‑recurring only 4% of revenue, improving quality of revenue mix.
  • Efficiency: CAC ratio 0.56 and LTV:CAC 6.5 support efficient growth; Rule of 40 at 63% shows healthy balance given scale.
  • Spend mix: S&M 37% of revenue is elevated vs 32% benchmark; Development 28% below 33% benchmark; G&A 20% slightly lean vs benchmark.
  • Retention pressure: Logo retention 85%, gross retention 79%, net retention 90% — consistent with Page ARR and Transactions showing recent churn/downsell episodes.
  • Profitability: EBIT -7% (near benchmark -6%); improving trajectory supported by margins and CAC efficiency (see P&L and Budget Analysis).
page2:
• Logos and land: Logos grew to 96 by Dec‑25; Dec‑25 quarter added 8 new logos and lost 4.
  • ARR movement (Dec‑25 quarter actual): Start £8.91m; Expand +£236k; Downsell -£45k; Attrition -£405k; Land +£720k; Net +£506k; End £9.42m.
  • Rates (Dec‑25 quarter): Logo retention 96%; Gross retention 95%; Net retention 98% within the quarter. Full‑year rolling NRR still ~90% (see ARR page) due to earlier churn.
  • Forward view: Forecast builds logos to 168 and ARR to £17.65m by Dec‑27, with moderate quarterly growth (6–10%) contingent on sustained lands and improved retention.
  • Action: Maintain new‑logo velocity while prioritizing saves/expansion in at‑risk cohorts to lift rolling NRR back to ≥100%.
page3:
• FY25 actual run‑rate: Revenue £8.38m; gross margin £6.58m (78%). Operating costs £7.17m (S&M £3.10m 37%, Dev £2.36m 28%, G&A £1.71m 20%). EBIT -£0.60m (-7%).
  • Trend: Loss narrowed through FY25; forecast turns positive EBIT from Jun‑26 and expands thereafter as revenue scales to £15.8m by Dec‑27 and opex ratio falls.
  • Unit economics: CAC ratio ~0.56 (Dashboard) with LTV:CAC >6 supports lower future S&M % while sustaining growth.
  • Headcount: 64 at Dec‑25 (Dev 29, S&M 21, Gross/COGS 10, G&A 4). Forecast growth to 106 by Dec‑27 with emphasis on Dev and GTM capacity.
  • Actions: 1) Rebalance S&M productivity to reduce S&M % toward low‑30s in 2026. 2) Hold G&A growth below revenue growth. 3) Fund CS/renewals to curb churn without materially lifting CAC.
page4:
• ARR by vertical: Energy & Utilities £3.95m (leader), Life Science £2.50m, Government £1.31m, Finance & Professional Services £0.90m, 3rd Sector & Education £0.77m.
  • ARR by region: South America £2.18m, Asia £2.09m, North America £1.87m, Africa £1.86m, Europe £1.42m.
  • 12‑month bridge (to Dec‑25): Land +£4.41m; Upsell +£619k; Downsell -£270k; Churn -£878k → ARR £9.42m.
  • Retention KPI (rolling): NRR trended down from 114% to ~90% by Q4‑25; gross retention ~90% overall. Concentrated churn visible in a handful of larger customers (customer table).
  • Mix implications: Strength concentrated in Energy & Utilities and Life Science and in South America/Asia; Finance & Professional Services shows net drag (ties to Page 5).
  • Actions: 1) Vertical playbooks for E&U and Life Science; 2) Dedicated save/expansion motions for Finance & Professional Services; 3) Regional CS coverage in Africa/North America where losses surfaced.
page5:
• Period: Oct–Dec 2025 actual. Net +£506k ARR across 17 logo events (8 new, 4 lost, 4 expansions, 1 downsell).
  • Composition: New +£720k (8 logos), Expand +£236k, Lost -£405k (4 logos), Downsell -£45k.
  • By vertical (net): Energy & Utilities +£461k (largest driver), Government +£135k, Life Science +£180k, 3rd Sector +£90k, Finance & Professional Services -£360k (driven by a £405k logo loss).
  • By region (net): North America +£315k; South America +£135k; Asia +£90k; Africa -£34k (two notable logo losses totalling -£225k).
  • Customer highlights: Multiple £90k lands/expansions; notable churns include -£90k and -£135k tickets in Africa/North America.
  • Implications: New‑logo engine is healthy; retention volatility is concentrated in a few accounts and in Finance & Professional Services/Africa.
  • Actions: 1) Rapid root‑cause on FP&S churn; put executive coverage on top 5 at‑risk accounts. 2) Standardize save offers (term extensions, phased pricing) for £90–£135k bands. 3) Replicate E&U plays that produced the +£461k quarter.
page6:
• Annual P&L vs budget (FY25): Revenue +£122k (+1%); Gross margin -£80k (-1%); Overheads +£189k over plan (S&M +£405k, G&A +£468k, Dev -£80k underspend). EBITDA -£595k vs -£625k budget → £30k beat.
  • Quarter to date: EBITDA -£53k vs -£128k budget (beat £76k); margin +2% vs plan; S&M overruns partially offset by revenue outperformance.
  • Month: EBITDA -£36k vs -£54k budget (beat £18k) with revenue +5% and gross margin +16% vs plan.
  • ARR vs budget: Year‑to‑date ARR +£382k (+11%) ahead of plan; additions +£329k (+8%); attrition £115k better than plan; downsell slightly worse; upsell -£41k below plan.
  • Takeaways: We beat ARR and EBITDA despite overhead overruns; variance driven by stronger new lands and better‑than‑planned logo retention late in the year.
  • Actions: 1) Enforce S&M and G&A spend controls to bring both back to plan while protecting CAC efficiency. 2) Focus on upsell programs to close the -£41k gap. 3) Codify forecasting improvements given Q4 volatility in churn and expansions.
